member.name: T:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder
member.summary: Provides a high-performance, allocation-free string builder using pooled buffers and stack allocation optimizations. Designed for critical path operations where minimal memory allocation and maximum performance are required.

remarks.para:
Key features:
Uses for buffer management to reduce GC pressure
Aggressive inlining of hot-path methods for near-native performance
Efficient bounds checking using unsigned integer comparisons
Growth strategy optimized for both small and large string scenarios
Ref struct implementation ensures stack-only semantics

⚠️ Important structural constraints:
Cannot be used as a field in classes or non-ref structs
Cannot be boxed or stored in heap-allocated collections
Cannot cross async method boundaries (including lambda captures)
Must be disposed after use to return buffers to the pool

Performance characteristics:
Append(char): ~2-3 CPU cycles (inlined fast path)
Append(ReadOnlySpan): ~1 cycle per character (vectorized)
Growth operations: O(n) but minimized by growth strategy

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance with optimized initial capacity
member.param: Expected capacity requirement. Default 32 balances memory usage and growth operations. For known large strings, set higher to minimize reallocations.
member.remarks: The actual allocated capacity may be larger than requested due to pool bucket sizes.

member.name: P:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Direct character access to the underlying buffer
member.exception: Thrown when index is outside [0, Length-1] range

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.Append(System.Char)
member.summary: Appends a single character using optimized path
member.returns: Chainable reference
member.remarks: Uses for near-zero overhead. Bounds check optimized using unsigned integer comparison (single branch).

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.Append(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char})
member.summary: Appends a character span using memory-copy optimizations
member.returns: Chainable reference

remarks.para:
Optimization strategy:
Early exit for empty spans
Pre-calculates required size
Uses Span.CopyTo for block copying
Separate handling for growth scenarios
Uses with explicit length for better bounds elision.

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.AppendLine(System.Char)
member.summary: Appends a character followed by environment-specific newline
member.returns: Chainable reference
member.remarks: Newline sequence matches Environment.NewLine (CRLF on Windows, LF on Unix)

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.AppendLine(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char})
member.summary: Appends a character sequence followed by environment-specific newline
member.returns: Chainable reference
member.remarks: Newline sequence matches Environment.NewLine (CRLF on Windows, LF on Unix)

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.ToString
member.summary: Constructs string from current buffer contents
member.remarks: Creates a new string instance. For zero-allocation alternatives, consider using the Span directly in downstream APIs.

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.Dispose
member.summary: Returns buffer to pool and resets state
member.remarks:
Critical for preventing pool memory leaks. Safe to call multiple times. After disposal:
All buffer accesses become invalid
Append operations will fail
ToString returns empty string

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.GrowAndAppend(System.Char)
member.summary: Handle buffer growth and append for single character
member.remarks:
Marked to:
Keep hot path compact in Append()
Reduce register pressure in common case
Isolate rare growth operations

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.GrowAndAppend(System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Char},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Handle buffer growth and append for character span
member.remarks: Avoids recalculating length during growth. Separated from hot path to prevent code bloat in frequently executed methods.

member.name: M:MelloSilveiraTools.Domain.Models.SpanStringBuilder.Grow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Grows internal buffer to required capacity
member.remarks:
Growth strategy:
Double current size (capped at Array.MaxLength)
Or requiredCapacity if larger than doubled size
Copies existing data to new buffer
Returns old buffer to pool

member.name: P:MelloSilveiraTools.Infrastructure.Database.Sql.Provider.SqlResource.InsertWithUniqueKeyTemplate
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to WITH CTE AS ( INSERT INTO #TABLE_NAME ( #COLUMNS ) VALUES ( #PARAMETER_NAMES ) RETURNING #PRIMARY_KEY ) SELECT #PRIMARY_KEY FROM CTE UNION ALL SELECT #PRIMARY_KEY FROM #TABLE_NAME #TABLE_ALIAS WHERE #UNIQUE_KEY_FILTERS;.

member.name: T:MelloSilveiraTools.MechanicsOfMaterials.Models.Fatigue.LoadingType
member.summary: It represents the loading types for fatigue analysis.

member.name: F:MelloSilveiraTools.MechanicsOfMaterials.Models.Fatigue.LoadingType.Bending
member.summary: Loading by bending involves applying a load in a manner that causes a material to curve and results in compressing the material on one side and stretching it on the other.

member.name: F:MelloSilveiraTools.MechanicsOfMaterials.Models.Fatigue.LoadingType.Axial
member.summary: It can be tension and compression. Tension is the type of loading in which the two sections of material on either side of a plane tend to be pulled apart or elongated. Compression is the reverse of tensile loading and involves pressing the material together

member.name: F:MelloSilveiraTools.MechanicsOfMaterials.Models.Fatigue.LoadingType.Torsion
member.summary: Torsion is the application of a force that causes twisting in a material. A twisting action applied to a generally shaft-like, cylindrical, or tubular member. The twisting may be either reversed (back and forth) or unidirectional (one way).
